Sincerely,

A wholehearted football fan from Spain.

Then, you can make our lives just like computer games. Make your goals clear. Define them. Search for the best options or ways to achieve that. Of course you need to define 'achievement' and feedback all of these processes. Enjoy your rewards, once you decide what to call 'reward'. That's how to live a happy life, or in this case play a good game.

As you can see, you need to define a lot of words and things. That's the most important, major step of constructing and planning your own life, a key to success. This is why you should know about yourself, listen to your inner voice, contemplate and stay a bit away from the crowds, phones, SNS and mass media more often.

By doing this, not only you can have a happy life efficiently and more profoundly, you can also be a more generous, kind and well-mannered person. You may fully respect other people's ways of living because you know they simply defined those words above in different way. You can treat them as they want based on the definitions and rules that they set!

So competition as we know it isn't real, because it is a self defeating idea in that the agents in play are seeking to complete their own puzzle's objectives better, faster, or more efficient than other agents in play; which would immediately denote that there are forces acting on the other agents' puzzles making it a game? You don't need to trip a runner you're running along side to act against them, you just need to impose the idea on yourself that you need to run faster than them and it stops being a competition. So all conflict is just inevitably a game to someone, which makes it a game for everyone in a certain capacity. But that's just a theory.

A GAME THEORY

I'm a much bigger fan of the one from Zimmerman and Salen in Rules of Play "A game is a system in which players engage in an artificial conflict, defined by rules, that results in a quantifiable outcome." If life is a game, death is not a victory. It's like Tetris; your failures are shown directly while your successes are hidden in the background. But the failures lead to more easily reached successes. Unexpected obstacles are thrown at you (and putting them in the hold queue isn't an option here) to slow you down, and we can only try to use them to our advantage.

We know it all has to end someday, yet we usually don't want it to. Every line we get is never enough, until you realize it was much more than you got last time.

So life is a game of Tetris, except Tetris is a puzzle, and we have one failed life rather than infinite failed lives.

My 2 cents on this is as follows:

As creatures get more complex & active, they develop bigger brains not only to operate their body, but also to allow for more complex planning & strategy.

This is clearly advantageous, because it allows for very useful behavior like pack tactics or long term memory. However, large, complex, active brains have a flaw -- boredom.

Such a complex brain must be powerful enough to do short bursts of intensive computation, but what is it to do when it isn't performing such a task? It's adapted to handle a high level of activity, just as an addict is adapted to handle a high level of their preferred drug. When intake stops, they get uncomfortable.

A brain powerful enough to do complex tasks gets used to them, & boredom becomes inevitable. The more complex the brain, the greater its capacity for boredom. Boredom, being unpleasant, is something to be avoided, but how?

Evolutionarily speaking, the most obvious choice would probably be to shut down higher brain functions when they're not needed, sort of like sleeping while you're still awake. This could, however, have serious consequences, such as making social interaction more difficult (because it would be limited to the times where all parties had total brain function) or making it difficult to react to sudden threats (as it might take a hot second for your brain to come fully online enough to properly respond).

You could argue that this does actually happen in humans (& presumably other animals) to some extent. During an adrenaline rush, for instance, alertness & reaction time increase, which you might think of as an increase in brainpower. Of course, we think of it as a positive increase, rather than thinking of our ground state as a reduced version of our full potential, but that's just a matter of perspective.

It still stands, however, that the vast majority of our brainpower remains at our disposal even when it's not used, causing boredom. The solution then is to find ways to occupy our minds.

With what is basically irrelevant, so long as it's doing something & we're interested in it, though some popular strategies include making things, telling or listening to stories, & playing games.

This would very neatly explain why animals can be observed playing, with more intelligent animals playing more & in more complex ways, & humans being the pinnacle of both (so far as we know, anyway). This gives a clear explanation for how play could've smoothly evolved from nonexistence to, say, chess. Like all things in evolution, it at no point spontaneously appeared fully formed.

In short, play is an emergent property of high intelligence.

This was easily extended to human with not just fighting and sports, but also with forms of social play that children are seen to engage with, which is more abstracted and therefore human, but still within that mammalian ambit of play.

There have been extensions from that into psychological game playing, politics, economics, game theory.

this pyramid for needs etc... it reminded me of something, and made me think... I COMPLETELY FLY OUT OF THE PYRAMID SYSTEM AFTER STAGE 2!!!

Let me explain: I have ADD, which lead to lost of friendship, and my friends noticed, that I became annoying... you could say that they left me on the side of the road called: society...

After being bullied, hated, mentally damaged by words, destruction, and depression... I gave up. I gave my feelings away, left every emotion except for Love and Seriousness behind and moved on. Nine years of „sitting on the road, watching old friends ignore me, watching society drive by...“ lead to this point. I got medicaments for ADD / concentration in college and I feel like I moved from my old body / mind to a new one, still organising everything... throwing out the boxes of depression, problems and pessimism.

But my friends... they were idiots... they didn‘t know anything. they don‘t want to accept that I‘m different. So I, as an individual... skipped the third part of the pyramid, and jumped to the last piece... Self-actualization... I make animations for fun, play an instrument, have hobbies, but I don‘t have friends... I solve puzzleboxes, solve all kinds of Rubik‘s Cubes, but I don‘t have friends... I don‘t want friends... now, they annoy me. They were the reason for depression... my ADD was just something that slowed me down... I don‘t NEED friends. Teamwork is something that never works out as good as working alone... at least not in high school or college.

I believe that humans like play because humans strive for conflict, and want to try. If we have an unconscious love for overcoming conflict, that's kind of an unconscious love for living itself, and a love which pushes us forward through life. We like a challenge and we like working to overcome that challenge. That's why our tv shows, our movies, and everything else is full of conflict, even happier shows have happier conflicts. Without conflict, we become bored, and if we feel as if can't control the conflicts in our life, we become apathetic. The desire to overcome in games is part of what makes us enjoy being alive. :)

They are the people that keep this world round.

One could make the argument that life has one thing that sets it apart from games : there are no iterations, no repetitions. In games you play, you either win or lose, game is over and you can play again. The reason we can't see life's reward may be that it never ends, or rather that it does, but only once.

And maybe the reason games can be so addictive is not only that they are interesting and rewarding, but precisely because there can always be a new game. There must be some comfort in the knowledge that whatever is happening in the game, you can get anoother try. This non-definitive aspect of games may be soothing, or even entraping, as all impressions of immortaly often are.

'Life':
Graphics 9/10
Physic engine 10/10
Story 6/10
Soundtrack 4/10
Replayability 1/10
Balancing 3/10

Conclusion: 'Life' is a pretty good Sandbox-RPG, but not quite the best. While itimpresses with its complexity, graphics and physic engines it has a pretty boring story, also its complexity requires the player to accomplish an 18 years long totourial. After you have learned the basic controls the totorioul is rly not worth playing anymore. The soundtracks are not included within the game. You must buy them, but you can choose any you want. Its a free to play game but also pay to win, although there is no goal. The replayability is just bad. You can play the game just once and you have no safe-spots, or save-points. For the balancing: as mentioned before, the pay to win system really makes differences between the player. Whether you have no Reallife currency or you just dont want to spend it for a game doesnt matter. Youll have a hard time not spending money.
At last, the game is worth playing. You should give it a shot. If you dont like it you may end it just like that. Good luck and have fun

Want a whole new can of worms? What is a sport? Many people classify that as a game of physical activity, but what about cheerleading, swimming and ballet etc? Most people do it individually, but all count as athletic sports. And sure, you can compete but always in a competition where you can't interfere with others. So are they sports or not? HUGE debate. And it gets even more complicated. Are Dota 2 and LoL e-sports? Does that make them sports? They have competitions where you are able to interfere with your opponents, so they are a game, but are they a sport? Is the requirement for sport to be physical activity, and does that have to be alone or with others, because alone, a workout at the gym could be a sport.

Echos the concept of flow by Mihalyi Csikszentmihalyi. The secret to happiness, as he suggests, especially those with anxiety depression, is to have not too easy, yet not impossible goals, that are clear and measurable. Similar to the Japanese concept of Ikigai. If people have goals, especially the retired elderly, they would have less time for confusion and delirium. Let's admit we all are confused, we all don't know what's out there, heaven or hell, angels or demons. Let's be comfortable in not knowing. Only then can we move on. Goals are really just a choice. I think if more people had goals, there would be less insane delusional people.

Wait … no Wittgenstein?

From his Philosophical Investigations, §66: "Consider, for example, the activities that we call “games”. I mean board-games, card-games, ball-games, athletic games, and so on. What is common to them all? a Don’t say: 'They must have something in common, or they would not be called games' a but look and see whether there is anything common to all. a For if you look at them, you won’t see something that is common to all, but similarities, affinities, and a whole series of them at that. To repeat: don’t think, but look! a Look, for example, at board-games, with their various affinities. Now pass to card-games; here you find many correspondences with the first group, but many common |32| features drop out, and others appear. When we pass next to ball-games, much that is common is retained, but much is lost. a Are they all ‘entertaining’? Compare chess with noughts and crosses. Or is there always winning and losing, or competition between players? Think of patience. In ball-games, there is winning and losing; but when a child throws his ball at the wall and catches it again, this feature has disappeared. Look at the parts played by skill and luck, and at the difference between skill in chess and skill in tennis. Think now of singing and dancing games; here we have the element of entertainment, but how many other characteristic features have disappeared! And we can go through the many, many other groups of games in the same way, can see how similarities crop up and disappear."


§67: "I can think of no better expression to characterize these similarities than 'family resemblances'; for the various resemblances between members of a family a build, features, colour of eyes, gait, temperament, and so on and so forth a overlap and criss-cross in the same way. a And I shall say: ‘games’ form a family.

And likewise the kinds of number, for example, form a family. Why do we call something a 'number'? Well, perhaps because it has a a direct a affinity with several things that have hitherto been called 'number'; and this can be said to give it an indirect affinity with other things that we also call 'numbers'. And we extend our concept of number, as in spinning a thread we twist fibre on fibre. And the strength of the thread resides not in the fact that some one fibre runs through its whole length, but in the overlapping of many fibres."

(By the way: this isn't just me trying to plug my favorite philosophers or something… I just think any discussion of the definition of "games" comes back to these passages in the Investigations at some point.)

Nice video but I'll tell you why we actually play games. Because we need problems to preserve our sanity after satisfying our basic needs like eating, drinking, socializing and feeling secure from predators etc... After satisfying your body you need to satisfy your mind and your mind, if you're not controlling it, creates you problems and asks you to solve them.The absence of problems drives a human being insane so he/she tries to "create" problems. No wonder neurosis is much more common among the rich than the poor and that's because of the lack of problems. We love and create problems in every thing we do other than trying to satisfy our basic needs. Watching films, for example, in every film there is conflict or a problem and that's why we love them. Playing games: when there is no problem to really threaten our being  we play games to threaten our virtual being in a game for example. There is a proverb that says: if you want to solve a problem give it to a busy man. And if you can't solve your problem then you don't have enough problems. Problems have no significance in themselves we add significance to them and playing games is a very good example of our need to have problems. So try and contemplate upon the problems and games that were of your creation...you didn't really need them :)

Nice video! Really interesting! Therefore, I think that there is something fundamental about the concept of games and sports; the fiction. In fact, what is the most important thing in a game? What does really count at the end? Of course, moves, tricks, shots, passes, are very spectacular and mandatory for a good entertainment, but nothing is more crucial than points, goals, victories, and ultimately records, history! However, everything that was accomplished in any sport you can imagine was and will always be virtual, it’s maths, it’s numbers, nothing else but inscriptions on paper! (more computers now) When it’s 2-0 for Manchester or 40-15 for Tsonga, scores are pure fiction, everyone  knows that these numbers will disappear at the end of the game on the scoreboard. You might tell me, yeah right, but these “virtual” points are worth billions! When you win 30 games in a season or you win tournaments, you become millionaire! When being the best in your sport, you become a legend, a venerated human for its accomplishments. That's exactly the point, many fortunate persons spend their entired lives playing the game they adore. Like it was said in the video, life is a game, and game is also life, at least for few of us.

Some of the things higher up in the Maslow's hierarchy of needs benefit the things at the bottom.  For instance, in order to have food and shelter in a civilization, you need to have a means to make money, which is where things like creativity and problem solving comes in to play, as those traits are necessary to be successful in your occupation.  Another example is that the traits associated with esteem (i.e. being respected) or sense of belonging can help you satisfy your safety needs - feeling secure in your job or your family.  I can also argue that morality is necessary for people to coexist with each other, as it discourages harmful actions and encourages altruism, which is beneficial to pretty much all needs in the pyramid.  So I guess what I'm trying to say is, in reality, our needs are actually a lot more convoluted than how the pyramid suggests.  The simplest way of looking at it would probably be that the physiological needs are actually your only needs, and everything else are just nice to have or otherwise means to better achieve or attend to your physiological needs.

Many things may happen in the game that they didn't foresee or expect. I personally think that we as humans play video games for three different reasons; competition, curiosity and creativity. We want to beat our friends soundly in a game of Starcraft, explore the worlds of games like Skyrim or Red Dead Redemption, or create massive castles in Minecraft or cities in games like Simcity.

There are a lot of video games that don't necessarily fall within that definition of "game". A lot of video games don't have clearcut final objectives or if they do, the player isn't solely driven to pursue that objective. Also many games can possess a very high level of uncertainty. Many people may pick up Skyrim with no desire to play through the main quest line, choosing rather to just explore or make up their own objectives to follow

on the one hand, you could say that the goal is simply to kill the end boss (the enderdragon), however minecraft is a sandbox game.
the unique thing about sandbox games is that there is generally no set goal for every (or any) player, but that you can create your own. since you can create your own goals and follow your own procedure to reach those goals, sandbox games do generally fit the definition of "game" as described in the video

So we call our game football for the same original reasons everyone else did.

How do you know, that Maslow's pyramid is emperically wrong?
. .
Isn't it at least true, that you will not be able to work on anything of the "upper parts" of the pyramid, as long as you are forced to achieve the basic tasks from the "bottom layer".
. .
I'm sure there is at least a hierarchy of fulfilling you "basic needs to survive" first!

Maslow's pyramid is empirically wrong (there's no hierarchy).
Tough your point being "we (and other animals) don't just make stuff to survive" is acceptable.

Now going for a reward model. Gaming as  a source of rewarding (usually social).
Taking sports, we see personal (players and teams) and collective (rooters) effects.
So what we end up is some sort of empathy and social effect making games cool. And some organisms using it  as a source of "fulfillment", "success" or "training".

Cliques and the importance of popularity are psychological phenomena emerging in childhood due to the state of brain formation. Cliques happen because children gain the ability to form social bonds in middle school years and seek those similar to themselves. Popularity has always been important among children because the part of the brain that handles social interaction forms more quickly than the rational part. This causes children to often have irrational obsession with popularity.

Animals that can regenerate lost limbs, can do so because of the high concentration of stem cells present in their body. so when they lose something, their body can quickly make it again. I believe the best definition of a game is an activity in which a player or players engage willingly, and overcome artificial constraints to achieve a goal. When football was becoming an organized sport in the UK it was played quite differently around the land. Soccer being the more popular sport in the UK people prefer to call it football, and rugby being more popular in the US people prefer to call it football aswell.

In our eyes, we have many chemicals that help us process different colours. When you stare at the sun, or any bright object, you use much of the chemicals. Since you used a lot of one chemical, and little of another, they have to balance. To Balance, they activate the chemicals of the colours un-used, giving an after-image, often looking like a negative of what we were looking at.

Our ear is shaped the way it is because it is meant to catch and bounce sound around it until it enters the opening. When it enters the opening, it hits the ear drum, which has its name because of its thinly layered skin. The skin vibrates, which you then interpret as sound. (Basically).

I actually split competitions and games by their adjudication rather than by interaction. (because it's one part of my two part criteria for determining whether an activity is a sport). If an activity is arbitrarily adjudicated (your result comes from judges), it's a competition. If it's objectively adjudicated (your result is determined by an objective measure, and adjudicated only for rules infractions), then it's a game.

It originates from a system in the brain that's devoted just to detecting where others are looking. This "gaze detection" system is especially sensitive to whether someone's looking directly at you (i.e whether someone's staring at you or at the clock just over your shoulder). Particular single brain cells fire when someone is staring right at you, but not when the observer's gaze is averted just a few degrees to the left or right of you (then different cells fire instead).

American football is called football because of its origin.  It, like soccer, can be traced back to rugby football where you use your feet to kick a ball at a goal or successfully carry a ball over a goal line.
